channel.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
channel.description:
After my [previous post](https://0x00sec.org/t/my-first-attempt-at-xss/13871) I‚Äôve been thinking about the next step, should I start a series where I implement all OWASP TOP10 vulnerabilities and then break them?
It could‚Äôve happened, but I decided to try myself at [hackthebox](http://www.hackthebox.eu). I had an account for almost 2 years, and all I had was 2 user owns in the last two months (which were *so* basic), and a couple of challenges done. A good first box seemed to be SwagShop, simply because I like earning stickers, and I thought this one would be cool (don‚Äôt worry, no spoilers here).
Long story short, after rooting SwagShop I just kept going and rooted another 3-4 boxes, in the span of 3 days. It was a wild ride, tons of new things to learn, same amount of frustration, but when I got the flag, it was all worth it - in fact it felt so good, I immediately forgot about the hours of staring at the screen murmuring >it can‚Äôt be that, it just doesn‚Äôt work
I‚Äôve went from noob rank to hacker during this time, so I thought it‚Äôd be good to capture what I thought during these few days, what I liked, what were the challenges that I faced, and so on.
## The Bad ### Enumerating non-web related services (like smb shares, rdp)
I come from a software development background, and more specifically, I‚Äôve been writing software for the web. This makes it easy for me to have a solid guess of the service if I see ports like `80`, `8080`, `3000`, `3306`, `5432` etc - but when `nmap` returned something like `445` - I had no idea what it was. In fact this was the first time I‚Äôve explored SMB following [this handy guide](https://0x00sec.org/t/my-hackthebox-ctf-methodology-from-fresh-box-to-root/13980/7) by @pry0cc . To ease my own pain, I‚Äôve bookmarked a [Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_TCP_and_UDP_port_numbers) that I can use as a reference.
### Looking at code requires a totally different mindset
At work we do a lot of pair programming (the bane of my existence) and whatever‚Äôs left is reviewed. If you‚Äôve ever worked as a developer in a team, you know that there are many things to check, code styling, design patterns, architecture, etc - but this is different, and I had to make that switch. One of the boxes had some source code online that contained key information of rooting the box. After spending a good chunk of time on it, I already came up with many points, but none of them were relevant! The important bit is to read the code and think about what the dev(s) could‚Äôve missed, if they forgot to catch an exception, or clean up some temporary data ü§∑üèª.
This was one of the hardest changes I had to make so far, but one of the most enjoyable ones.
### Off by one errors
I mean, we‚Äôve all been there right? Can you spot what‚Äôs wrong with `some_command /root/rot.txt`? I couldn‚Äôt - it was embarrassing. I cooked up a real cool python script, but did I mess up the operator and used `+` instead of `-`? Yes, I totally did.
I‚Äôm still thinking about this - but probably for my own scripts, I‚Äôll to stick to [TDD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test-driven_development) - it‚Äôs one of the things that worked really well for me in the past, and I think it‚Äôd help me to write more reliable scripts.
## The Good
### Reimplementing a CVE
What I‚Äôve found to be an absolutely good way to spend my time is to look at an exploit, and then keep rewriting it, so that a proper script is the end result. The one you can show in your GitHub profile, the one where if you need to make some changes or reuse it on another service, it‚Äôd be a pleasure to do so. It‚Äôs also great for learning more in depth about the vulnerability you‚Äôre exploiting.
### Automate as much as possible
When I first tried SwagShop there were constant resets, and brute forcing attempts, making it hard to even enumerate, let alone proceed.
Itüëè wasüëè utterlyüëè frustratingüëè.
Once the box was a bit more stable, I decided to design myself a workflow, so that I could get back to the part where I was without much effort. This worked wonders for me in other boxes as well - every time I was in the middle of something and the machine got reset, I could get back in within a minute and continue where I left off.
For certain boxes this can be as simple as recording the passwords you‚Äôve already obtained, but if you need to do something in order to get access, I encourage you to automate that bit.
## The Ugly
### Writing code
I‚Äôve tried - I really did - to write all my scripts in nano/vim/emacs whatever. I just couldn‚Äôt bring myself to it. I‚Äôve been spoiled by great IDEs that‚Äôll tell me how wrong I am, and offer rich refactoring functionality just to mention a few. I felt like I spent more time doing tasks that are just a shortcut away in my daily work, so I went back to using the IDE for writing scripts.
### Applying dev principles
One of the most useful principle I‚Äôve used is to go as _slow_ as possible. I could‚Äôve shaved a few hours off from certain boxes, all I had to do is just to download a file, run it, üí® shell‚Ä¶ but I didn‚Äôt.
If you go slower, you‚Äôll find more things when enumerating, you‚Äôll better understand the problems at hand, and you‚Äôll have a better chance of remembering the things you‚Äôve done, as opposed to just doing a quick hit and run. I think if you‚Äôre not having fun during these boxes, it might not be worth doing them anyway.
## Closing notes
I really enjoyed learning so many new things and techniques, and I‚Äôm definitely looking forward to get better at boxes.
I‚Äôd like to thank all the people I‚Äôve talked to in the last few weeks, they were all amazing and supportive people!

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: 0xf00f77
item.description:
I like your comment on reading the code in a manner differently than you would as a developer. It‚Äôs easy to feel like I can‚Äôt see the forest through trees at times, typically when writing something I have an idea in mind of what I want to be present, but looking through code for HtB I often find myself looking for what I hope isn‚Äôt present.

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.description:
Yeah, I‚Äôd dig that - I‚Äôll pm you

Read full topic

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: hacker_snail
item.description:
Thanks for the kind words - I must say, I really dig your blog, and the article is great too

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: hacker_snail
item.description:
I totally feel that! I‚Äôll not say ‚Äútry harder‚Äù, but what helped me is that I dedicated a whole day to the first box, and refused to give up until I got user. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre very close to cracking a box, keep it up!

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: c0wm1lk
item.description:
I honestly still haven‚Äôt cracked any box yet. I find it extremely frustrating, but right now I just keep trying, give a box an hour or three and if I can‚Äôt figure it out then I make a mental note to look up the solution later and learn from it. I hope if I keep that up for a few months that I might be able to crack my very first box soon

I usually make really stupid mistakes, like one box I had the username and password and pretty much pwn‚Äôd it but I just didn‚Äôt realise they were the username and password, so I kept looking and couldn‚Äôt find anything. After reading up a walkthrough I felt so stupid.

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: sequrist
item.description:
Good stuff! Also enjoyed your previous post on XSS. I‚Äôm also on a similar path, digging into infosec after roughly 7 years of web development (Rails, EmberJS, a bit of React). I approached the matter with CTFs and then trying some bounties on HackerOne; I posted my findings up to this point here.

Keep up the good work!

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: Nekiruy
item.description:
It was relatively painless, just the realisation that I had been doing the fundamentals in part for many years. Through Software Dev, CI/CD, automated deployments etc.

the transition was largely putting together that knowledge into a marketable skill.

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: hacker_snail
item.description:
Thanks for the feedback, how was the transition to DevSecOps?

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: Nekiruy
item.description:
Thanks for your post. I am in a similar boat to yourself, DevSecOps currently from a heavy dev background.
I also had a slow start to HTB, one or 2 boxes then a large gap and now getting back in with a VIP sub, my experiences have been very similar to what you describe here. and I totally agree with the sentiment of going slowly, I have made more progress going slowly through each tool and its output than I ever did running a few in parallel and glancing over their outputs.

Read full topic
item.source: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox

item.title: My thoughts after my first (real) attempt at Hackthebox
item.dc:creator: hacker_snail
item.description:
After my previous post I‚Äôve been thinking about the next step,
should I start a series where I implement all OWASP TOP10
vulnerabilities and then break them?

It could‚Äôve happened, but I decided to try myself at hackthebox.
I had an account for almost 2 years, and all I had was 2 user owns in the last two months
(which were so basic), and a couple of challenges done. A good first box seemed to be
SwagShop, simply because I like earning stickers, and I thought this one would be cool
(don‚Äôt worry, no spoilers here).

Long story short, after rooting SwagShop I just kept going and rooted another 3-4 boxes, in the span of 3 days.
It was a wild ride, tons of new things to learn, same amount of frustration, but when
I got the flag, it was all worth it - in fact it felt so good, I immediately forgot about
the hours of staring at the screen murmuring

it can‚Äôt be that, it just doesn‚Äôt work

I‚Äôve went from noob rank to hacker during this time, so I thought it‚Äôd be good to capture
what I thought during these few days, what I liked, what were the challenges that I faced, and so on.

The Bad

Enumerating non-web related services (like smb shares, rdp)

I come from a software development background, and more specifically, I‚Äôve been writing software for the web.
This makes it easy for me to have a solid guess of the service if I see ports like 80, 8080, 3000, 3306, 5432 etc - but when nmap returned something like 445 - I had no idea what it was.
In fact this was the first time I‚Äôve explored SMB following this handy guide by @pry0cc .
To ease my own pain, I‚Äôve bookmarked a Wikipedia article that I can use as a reference.

Looking at code requires a totally different mindset

At work we do a lot of pair programming (the bane of my existence) and whatever‚Äôs left is reviewed.
If you‚Äôve ever worked as a developer in a team, you know that there are many things to check,
code styling, design patterns, architecture, etc - but this is different, and I had to make that switch.
One of the boxes had some source code online that contained key information of rooting the box. After spending
a good chunk of time on it, I already came up with many points, but none of them were relevant!
The important bit is to read the code and think about what the dev(s) could‚Äôve missed,
if they forgot to catch an exception, or clean up some temporary data ü§∑üèª.

This was one of the hardest changes I had to make so far, but one of the most enjoyable ones.

Off by one errors

I mean, we‚Äôve all been there right?
Can you spot what‚Äôs wrong with some_command /root/rot.txt? I couldn‚Äôt - it was embarrassing.
I cooked up a real cool python script, but did I mess up the operator and used + instead of -? Yes, I totally did.

I‚Äôm still thinking about this - but probably for my own scripts, I‚Äôll to stick to TDD - it‚Äôs one of the things
that worked really well for me in the past, and I think it‚Äôd help me to write more reliable scripts.

The Good

Reimplementing a CVE

What I‚Äôve found to be an absolutely good way to spend my time is to look at an exploit, and then keep rewriting it,
so that a proper script is the end result. The one you can show in your GitHub profile, the one where if you need to make some changes or reuse it on another
service, it‚Äôd be a pleasure to do so. It‚Äôs also great for learning more in depth about the vulnerability you‚Äôre exploiting.

Automate as much as possible

When I first tried SwagShop there were constant resets, and brute forcing attempts, making it hard to even enumerate, let alone proceed.

Itüëè wasüëè utterlyüëè frustratingüëè.

Once the box was a bit more stable, I decided to design myself a workflow,
so that I could get back to the part where I was without much effort.
This worked wonders for me in other boxes as well - every time I was in the middle of something and the machine got reset,
I could get back in within a minute and continue where I left off.

For certain boxes this can be as simple as recording the passwords you‚Äôve already obtained, but if you need to do something
in order to get access, I encourage you to automate that bit.

The Ugly

Writing code

I‚Äôve tried - I really did - to write all my scripts in nano/vim/emacs whatever. I just couldn‚Äôt bring myself to it.
I‚Äôve been spoiled by great IDEs that‚Äôll tell me how wrong I am, and offer rich refactoring functionality just to mention a few.
I felt like I spent more time doing tasks that are just a shortcut away in my daily work, so I went back to using the IDE for writing scripts.

Applying dev principles

One of the most useful principle I‚Äôve used is to go as slow as possible. I could‚Äôve shaved a few hours off from certain boxes, all I had to
do is just to download a file, run it, shell‚Ä¶ but I didn‚Äôt.

If you go slower, you‚Äôll find more things when enumerating, you‚Äôll better understand the problems at hand, and you‚Äôll have a better chance
of remembering the things you‚Äôve done, as opposed to just doing a quick hit and run. I think if you‚Äôre not having fun during these boxes, it might
not be worth doing them anyway.

Closing notes

I really enjoyed learning so many new things and techniques,
and I‚Äôm definitely looking forward to get better at boxes.

I‚Äôd like to thank all the people I‚Äôve talked to
in the last few weeks, they were all amazing and supportive people!
